description: Latin radicatus, past participle of radicari (“to take root”), from radix (“root”).

entries.meaning: (botany) Having a root; growing from a root; (of a fungus) having rootlike outgrowths at the base of the stipe.
(zoology) Fixed at the bottom as if rooted.

verbs.description: radicate (third-person singular simple present radicates, present participle radicating, simple past and past participle radicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To cause to take root; to plant or establish firmly.
(intransitive, obsolete) To take root; to become established.
(transitive, arithmetic, rare) To extract the root of a number.
examples: Numbers, arithmetically, can be added, subtracted, multiplied and divided, exponentiated and radicated,  […]
